%s
I greet you, Warrior! We are the owners of these lands and we came to make sure that your army is not threatening our city. Can you confirm it?
It's true. We came from far away and we don't want a war here. An evil tyrant conquered our lands. His forces crashed our army and our troop went out for help.
We will help you defeat your enemy. First we need to reinforce our army. Would you and your warriors join our army and teach us the art of war?
Thank you for your offer. I accept!
This city hides many mysteries. We can try to solve them and use the knowledge we find to the benefit of our city.
I saw many scrolls in one of the caches. They seem to be something akin to diagrams…
Maybe these are the plans the ancients used to build their magnificent temples?
That must be it! The god Ptah heard my prayers! Now we too can start building beautiful temples and palaces! All we have to do is decipher these scrolls…
I greet you, Great Warrior! My friend and I have been wandering around the desert for many days already. Can we stay overnight in your camp?
We're not at war with the travelers. You can stay here as long as you want. But we're short on food. We can only offer you lentil soup and some bread.
Oh, thank you so much for your hospitality! Lentil soup and bread will do. By the way, we have grape wine. We'd be glad to give some to your warriors!
Thank you! Red wine will cheer up my warriors and give them strength. Make yourself at home!
I see your people stand steadfast, Nimiru, even in the face of certain destruction.
This city offers you no safety! Your finest warriors are under Amrun's control!
The Book of Life? Ha ha ha! Do you really think I'll believe it's regained its power? I'll execute the first captive at sunrise. The rest will suffer the same fate.
I always admired your strength, Nimiru. Perhaps you're on the wrong side of this war.
This isn't like you, Menes! Whatever this Amrun has done to you, it has corrupted your mind.
Now we have the power of the Book of Life! It'll help us defeat the evil!
Show him you are stronger than his dark magic. We need your skills to rebuild!
Dear, I don't mind if you live in our sepat. However, you aren't diligent about taking care of the bees. You don't seem to care.
Dealing with bees is not so bad… they make honey…
They stung me today. Yes, I care about the kids.
It's fine if you want to do beekeeping, but please find another place to do it… away from the sepat.
You've come at a difficult time. We are diligently fighting a battle with ancient forces of evil, and everyone in the city is trying to contribute. What can you offer, outlander?
Greetings, Chief! I travel to various lands and let people try my wonderful brew. It replaces boredom with joy and relaxes a tired body.
What brew do you speak of? If such is possible, then we have a place for you in our city!
Ooh! The Gods themselves revealed its recipe to me in a dream. I called it BEER! Try it. I promise you won't be disappointed!
Yes, it's delicious, and so refreshing after a day in the sun! I'm sure my subjects will find your brew to their taste as well. Stay with us!
I accept your offer with great joy, Chief! I will be honored to stay here and build a Brewery.
Greetings, Nimiru! I have heard that you can answer any question. I am in desperate need of your help.
I am far from all-knowing, but I truly can help people find answers that they cannot find alone. Calm yourself and tell me what has happened.
Well, on the day I treated everyone in the city to my divine brew, I was very happy…
But in the night, I dreamed a strange dream: I was in my Brewery. It was just as full of guests, but it was in a different city.
What made you think it was a different city?
It seemed so magnificent… Its buildings rose up to the sky, and all the people were dressed in fine rich clothes and looked very happy.
I know of which city you speak! I am amazed that you can describe it so accurately. I'd like to learn a little more about it. Do you agree to help me do so?
Of course, fine lady!
Hey, Warrior, don't just sit staring at the floor. Have a taste of my BEER and drive your sadness into the desert!
I've already had a taste, friend. But today, your brew is powerless to help me. If anything, it only feeds my dark thoughts. Give me something a little stronger!
Oh no, giant. My brew is intended to bring joy, not despair.
I can't allow your dark thoughts to multiply. You'd better tell me what's wrong. Maybe I can help? I've seen and heard a lot in my time…
Very recently, I caught an enemy spy in the city, and on the same day, the Nomad returned from the desert and told us there's a huge army a few days' march from the city.
I fear I won't be able to save the city with my swordsmen this time…
So that's the problem. Alright, go home for now and have a good night's sleep. Come back tomorrow morning. I'll think of something - I have an idea already.
Good morning, Farmer. Will the harvest be plentiful this month?
Greetings, Great Chief! Every day I walk around the fields, and I see that our crops have grown significantly. Neither rain nor wind could stand in their way.
So all the citizens will remain well fed.
That's good news. But we're going to have to tighten our belts all the same, no matter the harvest.
But why? Has the Nomad brought new people to the city again?
Yes, the Nomad truly has brought many people out of the desert, but that's not the problem. News has come to us from the Westerlands. Our neighbors are in need of help.
Menes's warriors burned their crops, and now they'll die of starvation if we don't share with them.
As you say, Great Chief. We've been through scarcity before, so we know what it's like. It is our duty to help our neighbors.
Listen to me, Nomad. You hunt, is that not so? Could you help me in my difficult labors?
After your incredible deeds, Brave Brewer, I'll make anything you want. Just ask!
My guests loved the fact that I started to serve various snacks with my BEER. With them, the citizens don't get tipsy so quickly.
I would be very grateful to you if you could do some hunting for me.
I promise to bring you meat every time I return from my travels. I might even manage to dry some in the sun for you.
Thank you, my friend! Business is booming like never before, and it was you who brought me to this city. I'll pay you well!
Oh no, friend. I don't have much need for money. It isn't as dear to me as it is to the citizens.
I'll be eternally grateful if you pour me a mug of your best BEER each time I return!
Greetings, Nomad! I haven't seen you since you brought the Brewer to the city. What new places have you visited, what things have you seen?
Greetings to you also, great Warrior! The desert holds many stories. The wind carries them through the air, and the Nomad remembers them and brings them to the people.
I can tell you much, if you can find the time to listen.
I will listen to your stories with great pleasure, my friend. For a mug of BEER, I might have a story or two for you as well.
Then let's pay the Brewer a visit. I heard he's already become an honorary citizen since settling here.
I think he might have a story or two to tell us as well. That man turned out to be far from simple…
Many moons have passed since our troops came back from the Temple of Amrun. I expected the warriors of Menes would strike back, but they did nothing… surprisingly.
We have only a few troops to defend our city. It's not enough. It's time we think how we can organize a regular army!
The granite deposits I saw at the foot of the Toothed Mountain meant we could make plans to mine this rare stone.
This is good, but we're still forced to buy many of the other resources we need to build the city from outlanders.
And that severely limits our options.
Hmm. I think it's worth trying to get at the other fruits of the mountain for ourselves. Which means we'll need to build a Mine.
That's a great idea! We have enough workers to start building it right now! Let's go!
In the ancient scrolls, I saw images of the magnificent temples our ancestors built on these lands before the city was destroyed.
I always dreamed of restoring them, but I could never find out how the ancient builders could build temples from such huge stone blocks…
Moving them from place to place would require supernatural strength… I think the gods themselves must have helped them.
Restoring the temples will make our city stronger and more powerful. But how can we make it happen?
Perhaps if we bring this beautiful stone as a gift for the god Ptah, the mighty god will reveal the secret of the ancient temples' construction to us?
Wisest Nimiru, I have brought you to this place for a reason. Every night, it appears to me in my dreams. My feet lead me here on their own, no matter how I resist them.
And what is this place, Brave Brewer?
I feel very strange in these ruins…. As if someone is trying to take over my body and mind… I've never been so scared in my life.
I see letters on the stone foundations buried here in the dust. One of them has "Amen" written on it… And on the other, "Hotep". Amenhotep? Brewer, what's the matter with you…?
YOU SPOKE MY NAME, WISEWOMAN. I WAS THE MIGHTIEST OF THE EGYPTIAN PHARAOHS. THE GODS PUNISHED ME FOR MY PRIDE. I ASK FOR YOUR AID!
But what can I do for you, O Great One? What do you need my help with?
THE GODS TRAPPED MY SPIRIT IN THE STONE COLOSSI. WHEN AMRUN DESTROYED THEM ALONG WITH THE CITY, I WAS TERRIBLY WEAKENED.
RETURN TO THE COLOSSI THEIR PREVIOUS FORM. I WILL NOT BE UNGRATEFUL.
I feel my former power returning to me. Now I can atone for the sins of my former life and serve for the good of the people. I want to thank the people of this city, Chief.
We too are joyful for your renewed strength, Great Amenhotep. But what else can you bestow upon us? You already give us wise advice, inspire us and protect us.
The forces of Darkness do not sleep. I feel them growing with each passing day. Amrun wants to wipe your reborn city from the face of the earth and inhabit it with demons and scorpions.
How are we to oppose this uncontrolled power? We are a simple people, though brave. The blood of great people flows in our veins. But that is not enough.
I wish to resurrect the ancient Gods to help you. But I'm going to need time. For now, I give you my Fire. Build my totem in your city!
Chief, the people the Warrior brought here want to live among us, work in our fields and be under the protection of our soldiers.
That is good. Thanks to them, our city will grow quickly and become even stronger.
But Chief, there are so many of them that they have nowhere to live. Many of them live in other peoples' homes or sleep on the street.
You are right, this is a serious problem. It is well that you told me of this. We will start building homes for our new citizens!
Father, I saw the same pendant around the priestess's neck like Mother had when I was in the temple. Where did she get it?
Your mother died. That's all you need to know. Forget everything you've seen.
But I don't want to forget! She's my mother! And I want to know the truth!
The truth is that treachery befell our family many years ago. Now we must learn to leave without looking back.
Father! I knew you'd come! Menes ordered the priestess to prepare me for the initiation. I'd rather die than agree to serve this wicked demon!
I know, Nimiru. You're a worthy daughter of your father! Many warriors and friends wait outside. They're ready to give their lives for you. Let's run!
Guards are coming here. Hurry!
Greetings, my lady! I trade fruit at the market in the Sepat, and I've come to ask you for your help.
I would be happy to hear you out, good woman.
Every day, there are more and more citizens in the city, and many of them come to the market, some to buy and some to sell.
Sometimes, so many people gather that I have nowhere to put my basket of fruit, and I have to go home without selling anything…
Would it not be better to take the market out of the Sepat and make it a separate place for trade, so that all may buy and sell everything they want to?
That's a wonderful idea! My thanks to you, good woman! We'll do just that!
However, we need someone who knows the merchant's trade well and can give us advice on how we should design the new market… Perhaps you could help us?
I'll be only too happy to help!
My market stall was robbed this night!
They left a note threatening me with punishment if I let this get out. I ask you for protection, Chief, and for justice for these criminals!
We cannot negotiate with such people. It is good that you did not fear their threats and came to me for help!
I will order my warriors to search the city and find what was stolen from you. And until the thieves are caught, I'll assign a guard to you for protection.
I know your market stall is all you have, so I'll ask the people to help you.
Each will bring to your home that which he can spare, and you'll be able to start trading again!
Thank you! I'm so grateful for your help!
As for these evildoers, I hope they repent and give themselves up to us. After all, the Gods' judgement will be far more severe than our own!
Respected citizens! An entire band of cunning and cruel thieves operates within our city.
We will do all we can to catch them. But while they are at large, we must be careful. Do not leave your homes unguarded or carry too much gold with you.
Know that from now on, anyone who is caught thieving will be subject to a public whipping in the city's main square!
This rule does not extend to women and children. But you, dangerous criminals, beware!
We caught the evil robbers, and now they'll be put in prison! Our countrymen can now sleep soundly again.
We'll return what was stolen to whom it belongs. But what are we to do with all the gold we found in their cache?
I doubt we can find the former owners of all these bars. Gold can't speak…
Hmm. We'll give the gold to the city. And to put it to work, we'll mint coins from it and use it for trade like they do in the other cities.
Now we'll have our own coinage too!
That's a great idea, Chief! Let's get started!
The Tradeswoman visited me in tears this morning…
Her little daughter has fallen ill and needs a remedy made from a rare and miraculous herb which doesn't grow around here.
To get this plant, I'll need to cross the Northern Desert. This is a very dangerous journey, but I just have to help the poor girl.
I'll start assembling a caravan immediately.
Traveling through the Northern Desert will be one of the most dangerous journeys I've ever taken! But we're doing it for a good reason, and that means the Gods will be kind to us.
Our journey must be successful! When the moon shows its new face, we'll return home and bring the medicine for little Sheriti.
Thank the Gods, we made it back with the medicine!
Let's hurry to little Sheriti! I hope it's not too late…
There he is! Hold him, hold him! Oh, how wild he is! And he bites too…!
Ahh, hey! Not touch! My food! Give!
Poor thing! It seems this man spent so much time underground, he forgot human speech. Hey, don't be afraid! We don't want to hurt you. Eat!
Nom- nom- nom! My food! Tasty!
His is the very voice I've been hearing by night! So he's the one who gave off those strange sounds…
But why is the staff silent now that we've found this tramp? And if he's been living underground for so long, where's his home?
Our people will never fall to the overlord Menes! We are a people with a great love of life, and this gives us strength.
However, even the most resilient of us sometimes fall into despair. Beer made from new types of grain will help the citizens keep up their morale!
I feel that the Gods have returned, that they are somewhere close by, but there is no solid connection between us yet. I must find confirmation of my suspicions.
Before the soul of the nomads' leader goes too far, I will go after it. If the Court of Osiris is in session, that means the Gods truly have awoken from their slumber.
Thievery is on the rise again in the city. This seems to be the work of a band that has sworn itself to the Shadow. Now that their master is gone, the thieves have taken matters into their own hands.
With Menes promising to take his revenge against us, the last thing we need is enemies appearing among the townspeople themselves. We must prevent this!
Surprise! Looking for your beloved Nimiru? Don't worry… she's in good hands!
Give me my daughter back, you brute! If you do anything to hurt her, you'll regret it!
Ha! What can you do? Nimiru will be initiated as a priestess of Amrun in three days when it's a full moon. She'll serve me! Forget that you ever had a daughter!
At long last, I'm home! I thank the brave warriors for risking their lives to save me!
Express your gratitude to your father, Nimiru. We just followed his orders.
Now our lands are well protected, and many worries are behind us. I would like to go hunting - want to keep me company?
I'm happy you accepted my invitation. Your friendship with the others in the city, regardless of your position, is a great honor.
Menes' servants haven't been bothering us lately. But you know as well as any how tough it is for me and my soldiers to live in peaceful times…
I would like to head off into the desert for a few days with my recruits to train them a bit. The tough life on the road will harden them!
The warrior headed off into the desert with his recruits a while ago, and we haven't heard from them since. I hope they didn't fall into yet another ambush set by Menes.
We haven't heard anything from our enemies in a while. I'm sure they want to stir up some trouble, and the warrior doesn't have his usual experienced troops with him this time.
Using a truth elixir we were able to find something out from a prisoner. He was a scout from Amrun's army, though he and his brothers belong to the same tribe as our nomad.
It looks like Menes is adding new forces to his army. My people are wild and ruthless. This will be a tough test for us: soon we will be face to face with them.

That will happen sooner than we think. As far as I can tell, the enemy forces are already right across the river. To make matters worse, Nimiru is unconscious and the warrior is grieving the death of his recruits.
We let our guard down once we believed that our city was in the clear. That brought us a number of misfortunes.
My father and I were obedient puppets in the crafty hands of the enemy. Evil entered our city and hid in the shadows. We need to remember that we have to fight until it has been defeated.
We delivered a devastating blow to Menes. I felt his fear and would like to say with confidence that he is a normal person. And today we reminded him of that.
Although winning the last battle was tough, and we almost lost, our troops were able to get out of the scrape and hand Menes a defeat.

After the magician betrayed his people, quite a few nomads, frustrated by his flight, decided to come over to our side. So far they're living outside the city, since they aren't used to living in a closed-up space.
But sometimes they visit the market square and the brewery. However, there has been a lot of theft in the city since they came. Could the nomad people really be repaying our kindness like that…
Something strange is going on in our city. I feel a strong vibration of energy around everything living. It's like something unbelievably strong has awoken.
I think some kind of ancient forces of nature have awoken directly under the city and are taking on physical form to enter our world.
We have always been able to handle whatever danger the desert threw at us. Now there is a new danger settling within our city walls. We need to eradicate it.
We created the White Lotus squad manned by townspeople able to stand up to the Shadow and everyone who decides to side with it.

The nomad does a great job training animals. The warrior has already battled the Shadow in the past. Nimiru controls magic, and the miner knows the underground world like the back of his hand. Good luck!
I lived in the Sepat for a long time while my pottery was being repaired. In that time my feelings for the Lady took on new life.
I think she and I need to take the next step in our relationship and have kids. And also I need to get back to work - I've lost so much time…
Rumors are going around that the Shadow gang is growing every day. We have tried so hard to make life safe for the townspeople, and now some of them are paying us with these coins…
When the city starts thriving, some people soak up its gifts and forget to be thankful. Unfortunately, there are very few other examples in history…
Wise Nimiru, the mummy we met underground, turned out to be one of the two sons of Egypt's last Pharaoh. The brothers were twins, one named Horus and the other Menes.
That can't be! Our enemy Menes was a prince of Egypt many years ago. But he became so evil, and what happened to his brother Horus? Why did he turn into a walking mummy?

Horus told me that Menes was obsessed with a thirst for power, became a servant of Amrun, and buried his brother in a prison, after which Menes was cursed. But Horus thinks Menes can still be brought back to the path of light…
The Shadow broke the seal on the door to the Underground City. I am terrified of that, but now the Shadow won't bother us anymore and the Underground City can be studied.
We find many interesting thing in secret city. We see strange demons. And in city live many cats. Now animals go to top…
So many cats have appeared all over the city. That's a good sign. Sheriti took in two of them and would like to help them further.
I think that's a worthy pursuit. I'll talk with my own kids, maybe one of them would like to help Sheriti. In the meantime, she's welcome to take care of her cats at the Sepat.
Thanks! Sheriti will be very thankful.
Father, we learned a ton about our ancestors from the books we found. We also found a lot of masks that look like the ancient gods. I suggest putting together a celebration in their honor.

I think that's a great idea. You will share your new knowledge with the townspeople at the celebration and I will put together some tests of strength for anyone who wants to join in honor of our gods.
I'm glad you liked the idea. Let's get to work organizing it.
Stupid little people, you dared dig into my past! Who allowed you to release Horus, my favorite toy? Did you think your actions would go unpunished?
You're having fun as if Egypt is just how it used to be and the gods have returned. I saw the true power of Egypt. You are nothing more than stupid barbarians living in a dirty village.
Slaves should know their place at the feet of Amrun, my master. Soon you will behold his true power!
O Gracious Nimiru, what is this sorcery? Why have clouds covered over the sky and started raining cold white flakes on the city? The citizens are in a panic, they're freezing.
This is SNOW, I read about it once. Snow usually falls in the northern countries, across the sea and far away, but not here. This must be the magic of Amrun and his faithful servant Menes.
But what should we do now, O Wise One?
You alone possess secret knowledge, and we need your help. People may start dying from this cold soon. The crops are already freezing in the field.
I'm as confused as you are, I don't know what to do. Nothing like this has happened before in my lifetime. I don't know the answer yet.
Go before the people and tell them that our Lord will soon hand out warm clothes. Tell them to light fires in the meantime.
As you command!
Greetings, Master. I've noticed a few times that you sometimes turn to ancient scrolls on celestial events.
I took the liberty of reading a few of these scrolls, and the knowledge in them amazed me.
That is so, Wise One. Before I settled in this city, I met the stargazer who told me much of the connection between the earthly and celestial planes.

Is it true that our ancestors named the groups of stars in the sky? And when these groups behaved strangely – disappeared, became brighter or changed their position in the sky – this affected us, the people?
Yes. People are connected to the stars. Our actions also influence the stars. The stargazer told me that this is because our ancestors came to this world from the stars themselves.
I would like to understand this incredible connection so that I can teach it to our Lord and help the people of this land. Will you help me, Good Master?
I would be honored, Wise One. I don't possess power like yours, and would be glad to help you understand these scrolls so that you can reveal new knowledge in the future. And so that I can record it.
It seems we're in times of peace, Chief. Our enemies haven't infiltrated our city or done us any harm for a long time. More importantly, we were able to drive Amrun's forces far way.
That's true, Warrior. You serve our people well. Thanks to you, we've been able to escape many disasters and expand our borders.
I would like to leave some of my soldiers here to defend the city while I sail to neighboring lands with the mariner and a few select men.
I understand how you and your men feel. You're not the kind to sit and do nothing. And more importantly, it will be good to solidify our new territories and show Amrun that we do not fear him.
With your permission, I'll tell my boys we can depart soon.
Of course, but remember, you must be careful in foreign lands. Don't harm those that are weaker than us – protect them however you can.
Your wish is my command!
Chief, I'm bringing more and more new people into the city. Many of them want to live among us, work in our fields, and be under the protection of our soldiers.
Yes, Nomad. Thanks to you, our city grows with each passing day. You have brought many worthy people who have become respected residents of our city.
But Chief, there are so many of them now that they have nowhere to live. When I bring them with me, I promise them comfort.
But the ones I brought back last time have had to crowd into other peoples' homes, or sleep on the streets or in the mine.
You're right, this is a serious problem. I'm glad you told me about it. We'll start building homes for our new citizens.
Who are you, stranger, and how did you come to these lands? Do you remember your name and where your home is? My people found you on the bank and thought you'd drowned.
I am the Mariner, and I have roamed the seas much. Recently, it has brought me nothing but grief. I want to forget about it…
Roamed the seas? Mariner, can you truly sail ships?
Not only sail them, Great Chief. I know much about seafaring and shipbuilding.
I can predict the weather and navigate by the stars. I know how to lure and catch many fish.
These are all valuable skills, my friend. Would you like to stay in our city and help my people build a Port? Fate itself brought you to our city!
I would gladly accept your offer, and of course I will help in any way I can. But I would rather stay away from the open sea.
As you wish! Then make yourself at home and freshen up. New clothes and food will be brought to you. Tomorrow, we'll start building the Port.
Greetings, Mariner. You haven't been in this city long, but you've already done so much for its citizens. My name is Nimiru, I am the Chief's daughter.
I have heard of your beauty, my Lady. I am pleased to know that you have heard of me. I enjoy being useful to the citizens by working in my chosen trade.
These days, I read much in the scrolls about the inhabitants of the sea's depths. It seems the underwater world is full of variety.
I've heard that you've been at sea yourself more than once, and seen much more than those who live on land. May I come to you with questions from time to time?
It would be my honor, finest Nimiru. However, the ocean's depths sometimes hold such terrible secrets that I would not wish to taint your gentle ear by telling you of them.
For me, all knowledge is sacred - therein lies my strength. Aside from that, I've seen many horrors myself in my time. I'm not easily frightened.
As you wish!
What business have you with me, Warrior and Mariner? Your alarmed and frightened expressions bode ill. Do you come bearing bad news?
Oh Chief! A giant monster has settled on our shores. It has many tentacles it uses to drag people down to the depths and destroy homes on the coast.
I doubt this monster will come onto dry land. The people will be safe as long as they stay away from the water. But while that creature is there, the sea is closed to us.
Many dangers have threatened us before. More than once, we've had to deal with sorcery and the treachery of Menes and Amrun's other servants. We can overcome this monster!
I've never seen anything like it, Chief. I think this creature come to us through hundreds of thousands of years. It conjures cold terror even in me.
If everything you say is true, I must see this creature with my own eyes. I want to know what this monster is and what it is called.
Oh courageous Chief, this creature is called the KRA-KEN…
Finest Nimiru, I had a vision. It showed me a giant creature with the body of a man and the head of an ibis walking through the city's streets. In its hands, it held scrolls.
I think I know what you speak of, brave Brewer. It is the ancient God of Wisdom - Thoth. I think your vision foretells something good for us.
At the end of the vision, Thoth approached the doors of the Papyrus Mill, shrank, and went inside. I think this is somehow linked to the Master.
That makes sense. There are many valuable scrolls in the Papyrus Mill. Maybe the revived powers of our city will soon reveal themselves.
Let us not hurry events.
As you wish, Unequalled One!
Nomad, my friend, I can't live like this any more. I'm glad I settled in your city, glad that I could work my trade and teach it to others. But it's not enough…
What's missing, my friend? The people of this city love you. You gave us much new knowledge, unlocked the expanses of the ocean to us, taught us to feed ourselves from its depths…
Could it be… the woman?
You are right, Nomad. When those tattooed pirates attacked my city, and those indomitable fishmen climbed out from the depths, a battle took place.
Many died that day. I searched for my beloved, but I could not find her. Then I wound up in chains on a galley.
That's a terrible tale. Many of us lose our loved ones in hard times.
I too loved a girl once. She was taken by a sandstorm. Maybe that's why I wander so I much – searching for her. But that's not what I live for. I live to be useful to our people.
You're probably right, but I can't seem to accept it yet. For now, I still battle with thoughts of how I lost her every day…
O Great Chief and finest Nimiru, I have brought you to the river bank to show you something that emerged from the fog today at dawn.
At first I thought it was some kind of building, but then I crossed over to the western bank and realized it was a giant Ship.
I'm astounded. This Ship truly is giant. All our citizens and their livestock could climb aboard it and there'd still be room for more.
It looks very ancient, like that strange building jutting out of the fog in the North.
This Ship must have been built by the people who lived in these lands before us. I always knew that the fog covering the northern part of the city is no danger to us.
On the contrary, it most likely protects the secrets of the civilization that came before us.
Now the Gods favor us, and have lifted the veil on the secrets of the past by showing us this Ship…
I crossed to the opposite bank. I couldn't wait to take a look at this incredible Ship!
Unfortunately, it's in a poor state right now…
It seems it suffered some kind of calamity. It's surrounded by giant boulders on all sides, preventing anyone from getting inside.
I think we should remove the boulders and make our way aboard to find out what this Ship is hiding.
Assemble a group of workers to take care of it, Nomad. I appoint you as their foreman.
If we can uncover the secrets hidden inside the Ship, we may be able to learn much of the people who settled these lands before us.
Perhaps we'll even learn the secret of the strange building towering in the North?
Chief! My men have successfully cleared the boulders that surrounded the remnants of the ship.
As long as the waters of the Nile cooperate, we should have the area excavated before dark.
We must find a way inside that ship.
If it's as ancient as you say, there's no telling what may be hidden within its hold.
I've spotted a breach in the hull with my own eyes, Chief.
I can only wonder… did something go inside the ship, or did something come out?
As soon as you can access this breach, go inside and see what your sharp eyes can find.
I already ventured into the hold, my chief. The ship is full of artifacts waiting to be catalogued. I took several to Nimiru for further study.
I must say, these are not normal artifacts, my Chief. Many of the items we discovered seem to be made of… coral.
Curious. Perhaps I'll head to the riverbank and see them for myself.
It may be wise to wait. One of my men fell ill after spending some time inside the vessel. I worry it may not be safe for any of us.
I found the antidote to the danger threatening the city just in time.
I think our predecessors were able to somehow protect themselves from it, and enchanted the Ship. It's all behind us now.
I'm glad it all ended without casualties. You did well, my daughter.
But in spite of all this, we gained much new knowledge of the masters of this Ship, did we not?
The Nomad and I studied many items and papers taken from the Ship's hold.
From what we can tell, the people who built the Ship had a deep knowledge of many subjects. They were more developed than us in all respects.
Well, if their knowledge can help us develop further, we must continue to study their culture.
All these strange items could make our life a good deal easier.
And we may even be able to discover the nature and purpose of that strange building towering in the North.
Judging by the scroll we found, the ghost was the Ship's Captain.
It seems he was the only one to stay aboard during the shipwreck, and was able to place his soul inside a crystal to leave a message for future generations.
So what do we know now about the Ship? Can we bring it into good order and take it out onto the water again?
I think so. It's just a matter of time now. We need to carry out some repair works and finish clearing the area to launch it again.
In the meantime, I'll get to the bottom of how the Ancients used the items we found to control the Ship.
That's great news. I'll go see your workers personally and offer them any help they might need.
O Great Chief, we are ready to finish repairing the Ship of the Ancients.
We'll get all the rock shards out of the way, patch up the breach in the Ship's hull, lay a new deck and caulk the seams.
Will we be able to sail on the open sea with this Ship?
We don't know exactly how to sail it yet. On top of that, we have no experienced seafarers among us.
In the meantime, I'll get to the bottom of how the Ancients used the items we found to control the Ship.
That said, Nimiru is sure we can use it to explore the nearby coastline.
With this Ship, I think we'll soon have more citizens in our city.
O Great Chief, we are ready to finish repairing the Ship of the Ancients.
And we'll establish relations with the other clans from the neighboring villages and towns downstream. Get started with the repairs!
What can you tell me of our Ship, my daughter? Have you learned anything new about it? Do you know how to sail it?
Father, it is truly a masterpiece of human creation! I discovered that the Ship is permeated with some kind of natural magic, emerging from the depths themselves…
Its Captain was an unusual man. Using the coral gloves and the powers of his mind, he could change the Ship's course with one wave of his hand.
I wouldn't be surprised if it could take flight this way…
How could one man do all this?
In the scroll, it is written that all the Ship's important parts are made of a certain material which we mistakenly took to be coral.
But I couldn't find out what this material really was. It's as if it came to us from another world.
I think we will find the answer we seek in that mysterious building in the North. But we're not yet ready for that…
You speak in riddles, my daughter…
Well tell me, is there one among us with the same powers as the Captain, capable of sailing this Ship as boldly as him?
There is one such among us, father, there is!
Our units are ready to defend the city!
Thanks for taking care of this!
Father relied on the fact that Menes's army is busy capturing the southern lands, and that no one would attack us while our troops are on the march…
But a safe home front wouldn't go amiss!
By joining our forces, we made our army stronger. Now we have a chariot and we're ready to battle!
Menes thinks we're small potatoes. That's good for us!
We will return to our homeland and win back our city from the tyrant!

Oh, Nimiru, something terrible has happened! I bought a bunch of medicinal cosmetics from a passing trader, and now there's nothing I can do: all the women who bought it from me complain that their skin is aged and wrinkled.
Could it really be the same thing that just recently happened to you? In that case, the whole city is in danger, and all of these women could turn into huge lizards.
Gods, what have I done… I just wanted our city's beauties to be even more beautiful! Now everyone thinks I decided to disfigure all of them on purpose.

I noticed someone has been stealing food from my house regularly. First sausages disappeared from the cellar, and then the fresh milk I had just gotten from the cows this morning. This has gone too far.
I can't believe the Shadow and the vagabonds who serve it have stooped to stealing food from honest people. This will not go unanswered.
Wow, what a good harvest! It makes me happy to see how green my gardens are and how full my fields are!
Look how many workers I have, all of them hard-working and well-trained. I can now trust them with even the most important things and focus my attention on a dream I've long had…
Oh, mighty gods! What is this? The underground city of the dead? Have we truly died and fallen into the kingdom of Anubis?
No, we're alive. But this really does appear to be some kind of underground city… Could it be the City of Sacred Beings?!
City beautiful. Miner live here long time.
This is unbelievable! The City of Sacred Beings is described in scrolls thousands of moons old! Many kings have sent their troops in search of it, but none could find it.
I think we should keep this find secret for the time being. For now, let's explore the city!
Dear, since the first time I saw you, a day never passed without my thinking of you.
I know I'm not worthy of such a favor from you… Won't you please be my wife?
Yes, on one condition. Promise me you'll be more careful in battle in the future and not succumb to the enemy's arrows!
I heard strange voices coming from the Sepat in the night. I couldn't sleep a wink because of them… Maybe it's your kids horsing around at night?
I doubt it was the kids. They spent all day helping the Potter clear an area to build the mine and went to sleep as soon as they got home.
And apart from that, I didn't hear anything of the kind myself…
That's very strange. Well, maybe I was just hearing things…

Unlock all the pages of the story about the Blue Lotus.
You have successfully completed the unique Legend of the Blue Lotus event!|June 17, 2019
Legend of the Blue Lotus
Ziyad successfully claimed the blue lotus from Nefertem and gifted it to his wife, reminding us all that with a bit of persistence, anything is possible.
That’s right, Sherity. And why do you think Ziyad was able to claim the lotus when no one else could?
That’s exactly right. It’s just like you and your beautiful orchids. If you want to win the flower competition, you must be persistent and unwavering in your dedication.
It sounds like you already have a good goal for next year as well. Good luck, Sherity. May you blossom and grow as beautifully as your orchids.
Wow, so despite his fear of water, and Nefertem’s riddles, Ziyad brought the blue lotus back to his wife?
It’s because he didn’t give up!
You’re right, Nimiru! I should enter my orchids into the festival! Although, between you and me, now I wish I’d grown a blue lotus for the occasion.
Complete the event levels and immerse yourself in an exciting story about the Blue Lotus. Fun experiences and valuable prizes await!
Legend of the Blue Lotus
Read

␣Once upon a time, the villager Ziyad, felt the urge to do something nice for his wife, Nailah. The pair had been married for decades, leaving the villager to wonder how he could show Nailah his appreciation for being a wonderful friend and doting mother, with the kindest heart he’d ever seen. He’d give Nailah the moon and stars if he could. He’d give her the mountains if they’d fit in his bag.|␣Gazing into the distance, Ziyad pondered the perfect gift. As his blue eyes scanned the horizon, they came to rest on the Forbidden Lake, situated past the mountains and through the valley.|␣The lake had always been a source of mystery and intriguing stories. In fact, Ziyad had heard other men in the village tell tales of the lake and a special blue lotus flower that grew from the waters at its center. Unfortunately, according to these same men, all attempts to claim the blue lotus had failed.|␣It was then that Ziyad knew what he’d give his precious wife to show his true feelings for her. He’d venture to the Forbidden Lake and be the first to successfully claim the blue lotus. Leaving Nailah at home, and setting off in the morning sun with a determined kick in his step, the villager had reached the shores of the Forbidden Lake by midday. |␣That was when Ziyad came upon his first obstacle.

␣Ziyad stood on the shores of the Forbidden Lake with the water lapping at his toes. Shielding his eyes against the afternoon sun, he could just make out the blue lotus rising from the azure waters. In his rush to claim the flower, the villager had forgotten once very important piece of information: he didn’t know how to swim, and had always been nervous around water.|␣The villager, determined to bring the blue lotus back to the village, pushed his fear out of mind and went about collecting driftwood from around the lake. After finding three large timbers, Ziyad secured the wood together using strips of papyrus. Pushing the raft out into the water, the villager used his hands to row toward the lotus.|␣Ziyad paddled with great care and patience and soon arrived at the lotus. The villager was confused. How could so many men have failed to claim the flower, when he had arrived with little opposition?|␣Looking down at the flower from his raft, Ziyad let out a gasp.

␣The flower was more beautiful than Ziyad could have imagined, and the villager didn’t hide his smile as he thought about what Nailah would say upon receiving it. He hoped it would make his wife feel appreciated and full of love, the same way she made him feel each day.|␣The petals of the lotus were a striking blue and the bulb was of rich gold color, that in the daylight, seemed to shimmer and glow. The longer the villager gazed at the flower, the more entranced he became. It truly was the most beautiful specimen he’d ever seen.|␣Ziyad was excited to have reached his goal, but his mind wandered back to the stories told by men in the village. Shrugging off his doubts, Ziyad reached down from the raft. Wapping both hands around the stem of the lotus, the villager gasped at seeing a reflection in the water.

␣Turning on his raft, Ziyad saw a man with darkened skin wearing a fancy headdress floating just inches above the lake. “Nefertem!” Ziyad breathed. “Why, it’s the god of flowers himself!”|␣Nefertem crossed his arms and gave Ziyad a disapproving look. “You attempt to claim the blue lotus, human?”|␣“I do,” Ziyad said, still holding onto the boat as it rocked gently in the water. “I want to give it as a gift to one that I care deeply about.”|␣Nefertem waved his hand, sending a small wave across the surface of the Forbidden Lake. “Many have come before you to take my lotus,” Nefertem said. “However, I’ve learned that man isn’t worthy of such beauty.”

␣“I am worthy!” Ziyad pleaded. “I seek the flower not for me, but for my beautiful wife.”|␣“Humans have always thought themselves clever,” the god began. “In all my years guarding the lotus of the Forbidden Lake, I’ve seen countless men journey here only to leave disappointed. And now you… you expect me to simply give it to you!”|␣“There must be something I can do to prove my worth, oh powerful one,” said Ziyad.|␣Nefertem rubbed his chin, considering Ziyad’s offer. “Prove your cleverness, then,” said the god. “I have three riddles and if you can answer even one of them correctly, the lotus is yours.”|␣Seeing no other option, Ziyad agreed to Nefertem’s proposal. The villager didn’t consider himself to be very good at riddles, but he could feel his raft coming apart beneath him. Time was not on his side, and he wasn’t going to leave without the lotus.|␣“Let us begin,” Nefertem said, smiling slyly. “What always runs but never walks, often murmurs, never talks, has a bed but never sleeps, has a mouth but never eats?”

␣Ziyad’s mouth worked wordlessly as he tried to solve Nefertem’s riddle. “What always runs but never walks, often murmurs, never talks, has a bed but never sleeps, has a mouth but never eats?”|␣But there, floating in the lake, the villager’s mind was blank.|␣“I… I don’t know,” Ziyad said with a sigh.|␣Nefertem laughed. “Of course you don’t, human!” he said. “The answer is ‘a river.’”|␣Suddenly, one of the papyrus cords snapped and a piece of driftwood floated away from the raft. Ziyad moved to one side, keeping his body on what was left of the makeshift boat. The villager fought his instinct to panic.|␣“Dare you attempt my second riddle, human, or perhaps you’d rather head back to shore?” Nefertem asked, his grin returning.|␣“I’m ready,” Ziyad said, focused. “Ask your riddle, Nefertem.”|␣The god cleared his throat, preparing his next puzzle.|␣“I am everywhere, but I cannot be seen. I cannot captured or be held. I have no throat but I can be heard. At times I am quite loud.”

␣Ziyad bobbed in the water, reciting the second riddle in his mind. “I am everywhere, but I cannot be seen. I cannot captured or be held. I have no throat but I can be heard. At times I am quite loud.”|␣The villager took a deep breath. “I do not know the answer, Nefertem.”|␣The god gave a throaty laugh. “I won’t pretend to be surprised by that, human,” Nefertem said. “The answer is ‘the wind.’”|␣Ziyad struggled to get a knee onto the raft and another papyrus cord broke. Another piece of driftwood floated away and the villager splashed into the lake. He surfaced moments later, flailing for the final piece of driftwood. Ziyad knew that if he let go, he risked drowning.|␣“There is no shame in giving up on the lotus,” Nefertem mused. “You wouldn’t be the first, and you surely won’t be the last.”|␣Despite the opposition, the villager would still not give up. “Ask your final riddle,” Ziyad said, sputtering as his nose dipped below the surface of the lake.|␣“Very well,” Nefertem said. “I can start a war or end one. I can give you the strength of heroes, or leave you powerless. I may be snared with a glance, but no force can compel me to stay. What am I?”

␣Still holding onto the driftwood, Ziyad repeated Nefertem’s riddle. “I can start a war or end one. I can give you the strength of heroes, or leave you powerless. I may be snared with a glance, but no force can compel me to stay. What am I?”|␣The villager’s wife appeared in his mind, and the thought of Nailah’s flowing hair and warm smile kept Ziyad’s panic at bay. He loved her so much, and for the first time, he feared he may not see her again, with or without the lotus.|␣That’s when Ziyad realized he knew the answer. “The answer is love,” he said, his voice full of confidence.|␣“That’s… correct,” Nefertem said, shocked. “How did you know?”|␣“If there’s one thing I do know in this world, it’s love,” Ziyad said. “I came to claim your lotus not for riches or notoriety, but as a gift for my beautiful wife. She is a strong woman, an amazing mother, and she’s as kind as the day is long. I walked from my city to this lake despite my lack of shoes, and I sailed across this lake despite my fear of water. Nothing was going to keep me from claiming that lotus. Not even your riddles.”|␣Nefertem’s eyes widened. “You really do know love, human. In all my decades I’ve never seen a love so strong and pure. In fact, you should be rewarded.”

␣Plucking the blue lotus from the surface of the water, Nefertem guided the flower toward Ziyad.|␣The villager carefully lifted a hand from the driftwood, reaching for the lotus. Before the villager could take the flower, Nefertem pulled it away.|␣“This lotus, though flawless, will only last until midnight, at which time it will return to me,” Nefertem warned. “I would urge you to not waste any time in getting home to your lovely bride.”|␣Placing the stem of the lotus in Ziyad’s hand, Nefertem faded from view. Suddenly, thunder cracked the air overhead and Ziyad shut his eyes as lightning streaked the sky. When the villager opened his eyes, he was no longer floating in the cold waters of the Forbidden Lake. Instead, he was miles away, safely back in his village.|␣Looking down, Ziyad saw the lotus in the palm of his hand and smiled. Without another thought, he turned and rushed toward his home. There he found his loving wife, and bestowed her with the most beautiful flower the world had ever seen.
Why, Sherity… those are the most beautiful orchids I’ve ever seen! Are you planning to enter them into the Flower Festival competition?
This could be the year you do win, child. If you want something bad enough, you must work hard… even in the face of adversity.
If that’s how you feel, then allow me share a story with you that may change your point of view…
Nimiru! Do you see these beautiful orchids? I grew and tended them all by myself!
I thought about it… but last year I entered my jasmine, and I didn’t win.
I’ll never win! I try every year and I always leave the festival disappointed.
Complete all the Magic Books levels to hear a new story from Nimiru.

I've lost my game progress. What should I do?
If your game progress is lost, try:
1. Restart your device.
2. Reinstall the game and reconnect to Facebook or enable iCloud, if the game was previously connected to game progress synchronization via Facebook or iCloud.
If your progress has not been restored after these actions, please contact our support department.
You can try restoring your progress yourself by tapping the "Restore Progress" button.
Only your game level and crystal balance will be restored. Are you sure you want to restore?
How do I save my game progress?

Game progress is saved automatically if your device is connected to the Internet. To play on multiple devices at the same time and avoid losing your game progress, enable game progress synchronization via Facebook or iCloud.
Important!

After restoring your device's factory settings, check that game progress synchronization via Facebook or iCloud is enabled. If it's not, you won't be able to restore your Cradle of Empires progress on your own.

Achievements
Profile
Anubis allowed me to meet the Old Magician's Spirit. He uncovered the secrets of the past.
Can you tell me what he told you?
Father, I have no secrets to hide from you. He said that the Emperor's son, who destroyed the Book of Life a few centuries ago, was…
Oh, don't keep me in suspense, Daughter! My friend, don't you want to know this secret too?
I'm sorry to tell you, Father, but the Emperor's son is… It's Menes…
How is it possible?! It was many centuries ago! People don't live for so long!
It was probably black magic. The Magician's Spirit grew tired and disappeared. We have to wait until he regains his strength.

It's the season of giving thanks as we gather with friends, relatives, and loved ones to show that we're grateful for the many blessings in our lives. Of course, we're so thankful for you as well! May your autumn season be full of wonder.
Give Thanks!
The Portal of Worlds will take you to the Indian Village! Are you ready for new adventures?
Lower all the turkeys
The Portal of Worlds will take you to an Indian Village! Are you ready to embark on new adventures? Don’t miss the start of the event on September 22!
Don’t make us celebrate without you! Return to the city for a Thanksgiving gift!
Your people may have regained some hope with your miraculous recovery, Chief, but let's see how they react when your daughter joins my army!
You stay away from Nimiru! Do you hear me, Menes?
You kept us apart! A mistake for which you'll now pay! Your people run for cover… your very city crumbles around you!
Leave the city now, before it is nothing more than a distant memory.
Why are you doing this, Menes? With what promises has Amrun poisoned your mind?
Poisoned? Amrun has show me truth, and my loyalty will be rewarded.
Even your gods cannot save you now!
Amrun is using you! You're a high priest, skilled in the magical arts. He will toss you aside once his agenda has been fulfilled!
You can help us, Menes. You can protect your city… protect Nimiru! I will only ask once, and I beg you to take my offer.
Hrmph. He's disappeared again. If Menes won't be our ally, then he shall be treated as the enemy.
Unlock all the pages of the story of three wishes.
You have unlocked all the pages of the story of three wishes.
Fairy Tale: The Three Wishes
Unfortunately, you didn't get to the end of the storybook. But never fear, new and exciting stories are ahead!
Nimiru's tale came to an end. Garib and Amira lived happily ever after, but that's another story…
But, Sheriti, that's not what the message of the story was! Come here. I'll tie your hair up with a pretty ribbon.
Ummm… yes! The ribbon is indeed magic. It will help you find the right words once you decide to speak with that boy. It will also make you… umm… drop-dead gorgeous.
That was a great story! You know, I've changed my mind. Let's not make that boy forget about the second girl – we can just turn the girl into a toad!
Yeah, yeah, I know what the story was about. Am I not allowed to make jokes now? What do I need the ribbon for? Is it magic or something?
I'm sorry but you can't exactly call that magic. I'm drop-dead gorgeous as it is! Finding the right words does sound kind of nice though… Fine, the ribbon it is. Let's give it a shot.

Complete a level to find a part of the picture

␣This story happened a long, long time ago, and while many have heard it, few believe it. Take heed, though, because every word is true.|␣Once upon a time there was a handsome young man named Garib. He was a good man, but he had a bad habit of making friends with the shallowest of people.|␣In the same city lived Leila. While she was pleasing to the eye, she thought only of herself.|␣Then there was the timid Amira, who secretly adored Garib, even though she couldn't bring herself to speak with him—not even in her wildest dreams.|␣This is the story of Garib, Leila, Amira, and someone else, who you'll meet soon enough…
Chapter I

␣One day, as the sun shone brightly and the white clouds galloped across the sky like horses, the city bustled with friends happy to see one another—only Amira was alone and downtrodden. Hidden from view, she watched as Leila and Garib walked across the market laughing and smiling.|␣Amira wore the only frown in the entire city.|␣"Why would Gariba call Leila beautiful and sweet?" Amira thought. "She's not like that at all! Everyone knows she steals the hearts of those she charms, collecting them like pearls on a necklace. The more the merrier!"|␣Unable to watch as Leila leaned in and hugged Garib, Amira stormed off.|␣"If only Garib knew how much I loved him," thought Amira, trying her best not to cry. "If he did, he'd never give Leila so much as a second glance."|␣Suddenly, Amira tripped, falling to the dusty street. Unable to control her emotions any longer, she burst into tears.|␣"How could I expect Garib to ever fall in love with someone as awkward as me?"|␣- Looking around, Amira saw what she had stumbled over. It appeared to be an old copper lamp.|␣"If only it were a magic lamp, like in the fairy tales," Amira sighed. "Then my problems might be solved."|␣Picking up the antique, Amira rubbed the side, gasping as blue smoke poured out of the lamp.
Chapter II

␣As the smoke cleared, Amira was shocked to see a blue genie standing before her.|␣"Greetings, Mistress!" he boomed. "Because you've freed me from my lamp, I'll serve you until I fulfill your three wishes."|␣Overcome with astonishment, Amira's knees legs buckled and she nearly fell to the street a second time. Luckily, the genie created a magic bench behind her on which she sat.|␣"What does your heart desire, Mistress?" asked the genie. "Perhaps a mountain made of gold? Or maybe a sea of the world's most beautiful diamonds? How about a large, sprawling palace?"|␣"I want Garib to know how much I love him!" Amira cried out.|␣Amira's outburst surprised even herself. It was the first time she'd ever admitted her feelings for Garib aloud. The genie considered Amira's wish for several moments before he spoke.|␣"Is that really worth a wish?" he asked. "After all, you could just tell Garib how you feel…"|␣"I can't!" Amira wailed, lowering her head. "Every time I've tried, the words become stuck in my throat and my lips don't cooperate."|␣"Well, okay then," said the genie with a shrug.|␣Without another word, he disappeared in a puff of blue smoke.
Chapter III

␣The genie searched the entire city for Garib, finally finding him and Leila at a café, where they sat eating sweets and drinking coffee. Leila had ordered the most expensive items on the menu and Garib was trying desperately to woo her with his generosity, despite not having much money.|␣- "I only order the finest dishes everywhere I go," Leila said. "Can you tell I have expensive taste?"|␣Garib opened his mouth to answer but became distracted when a blue elephant with a trumpet-shaped trunk burst into the tent.|␣"Attention, everyone!" the elephant began, singing in a human voice. "Amira loves Garib! Amira loves Garib! Just like a field loves rain, a bird loves the wind, and the fishes love the sea…Amira loves Garib! Amira loves Garib!"|␣As the elephant began to trumpet loudly and dance around the room, café patrons flocked close to watch the spectacle.|␣"He must be singing about you, Garib," Leila said. "But who is Amira?"|␣Garib shrugged. He didn't know.|␣"Whoever Amira is, she must be someone truly amazing for her to have taught an elephant how to dance and sing!" offered a nearby patron.|␣"She can't be more amazing than me…I've taught plenty of elephants to sing and dance," lied Leila.|␣Garib remained focused on the elephant, ignoring Leila's tall tales. In an effort to focus Garib's attention back on her, Leila laid a hand on his arm.|␣"You like music?" she asked. "I'll sing you a song about a beautiful woman named Leila and how she makes men's heart beat faster whenever she's near them!"|␣Garib rolled his eyes.|␣"Let's leave," he said, climbing to his feet. "It's too noisy here."
Chapter IV

␣"What have you done?!" yelled Amira when the genie reappeared next to her. "The entire city heard your song! People are going to laugh at me!"|␣"People may be talking about the elephant, but only Garib remembered your name," said the genie with a shrug. "Go to him and he will surely fall at your feet!"|␣"Don't tell me what I want to hear!" Amira said, stomping her feet. "I know that's not true!"|␣"My intentions were as pure as the morning dew," said the genie, swirling around Amira like a vine on a tree. "You must speak to Garib, it's the only way to know for sure…"|␣"I can't talk to Garib while Leila is near," Amira protested, tears welling in her eyes. "She's so distractingly beautiful that he can't take his eyes off of her. There's no chance he'll notice me!"|␣"Well," the genie began, rubbing his chin contemplatively, "I suppose I could always turn Leila into a toad."|␣"I don't want you to turn her into a toad!" Amira gasped. "I want you to open Leila's heart. Then, Garib will know for sure whether or not she truly loves him."|␣The genie nodded, disappearing in another puff of smoke.
Chapter V

␣As the sun set over the city, long shadows cast by buildings and totems fell on the sand. Leila and Garib strolled side-by-side through the twilight.|␣"A beautiful evening such as this makes me think about love," Leila said, smiling widely. "Tell me, Garib, are you thinking about love, too?"|␣Leila wasn't really thinking about love, but she'd say anything to take Garib's mind off the dancing elephant and the mystery woman.|␣"I am," Garib answered quietly.|␣"Then please share your thoughts," Leila exclaimed. "Except, let us first go somewhere crowded so passersby can hear how passionately you speak to me on the subject of love!"|␣Grabbing Garib's hand, Leila pulled him into a side alley that would lead them to a nearby park. Before the pair could exit through the other side, a large, hulking bandit appeared, blocking their way. The ferocious-looking bandit was twice as tall and four times wider than Garib.|␣"Look at these lovebirds…" said the bandit, who was secretly the genie in disguise. "It appears they have nowhere to fly!"|␣Laughing menacingly, the genie lumbered toward Garib and Leila.|␣While Garib wasn't normally one to be timid, the size of the bandit intimidated him beyond measure. As he turned to run, he saw Leila cowering behind him. Garib knew he couldn't abandon the woman. Calming the trembling in his knees, Garib turned back to the bandit, preparing for a fight.|␣"I'm too beautiful to die!" Leila yelled, shoving Garib toward the attacker. "Fight him for me, Garib! Defend my honor!"|␣Leila's push caused Garib to fall at the bandit's feet and he watched in horror as attacker raised a heavy boot. Covering his head and closing his eyes, Garib waiting for the blow to strike. When one didn't come, he slowly opened his eyes.|␣Garib realized he was alone in the alley. Both the bandit and Leila were gone.
Chapter VI

␣The genie returned to Amira, hurriedly describing to her the scene that took place in the alley.|␣"Clearly Garib loves Leila if he was prepared to fight for her," Amira sobbed. "And I tried to keep them apart! Tell me, Genie, am I a terrible person?"|␣"You're the kindest person I've met in my 10,000 years inside that lamp," the genie said, doing his best to console her.|␣"I don't deserve that," Amira said, pouting softly. "I could have avoided all of this if I'd just spoken to Garib and confessed my feelings to start with!"|␣The genie was touched by Amira's display of raw emotion. He flicked a tear from his own eye without her noticing.|␣"I believe I've learned my lesson," Amira continued. "From this day forward I won't waste time hoping for miracles. I'll speak my mind instead of remaining silent, and I'll move forward rather than stand still."|␣"You're wise beyond your years," the genie said softly, brushing a tear from Amira's face. "You do have one wish left, remember. Perhaps gold or diamonds will help you to feel better?"|␣"I'm through with wishes for myself," Amira said, pulling herself together. "My final wish is for you to be free."|␣The genie gasped. "You could have anything your heart desires, and yet you'd use your last wish to free me?"|␣"Exactly," Amira nodded. "After all, we're both slaves, genie. I to my timidness, you to your lamp. Why spend your years locked away when you could work wonders wherever you desired? Just promise me you'll do no harm with your magic. The world is full of enough sorrow, so use your magic to make people happy."|␣The genie stammered, not knowing what to say. "Yes, yes of course! You are the most generous mistress of all. I can't believe it…I'm free!"|␣Amira handed the genie his lamp and he disappeared into the bustle of the city.
Chapter VII

␣Following the run-in with the bandit, Garib stayed in the alley. He felt bad that Leila had abandoned him and foolish for thinking she actually cared.|␣Finally exiting the alleyway, Garib immediately ran into Leila.|␣"Garib!" Leila breathed, her face covered in shock. "What a relief to see you alive! Where have you been? I've been searching for you."|␣"I was right here," Garib spat, "where you left me."|␣"Don't be mad at me," Leila said, putting her hands on her hips to feign offense. "You're alive, aren't you? You could at least be appreciative of how beautiful I look tonight. After all, I did it for you."|␣"You could be as beautiful as a thousand stars," Garib said, turning away from Leila. "But that doesn't mean a thing if you're as dark as the night on the inside."|␣"Don't be so cruel!" Leila gasped. "I thought you loved me?"|␣"I don't," Garib said. "I hoped the beauty in your heart would match what you show on the outside, but now I can't help but wonder if you have a heart at all!"|␣"Oh, Garib," Leila mused. "You're speaking nonsense! Why must you worry so? Come, we're both young and beautiful…we should be out dancing, not arguing near a dark alleyway."|␣"You go," Garib said. "I need some time alone to think about what it is I truly want."|␣Not waiting for Leila to answer, Garib turned and headed home.
Chapter VIII

␣After freeing the genie, Amira headed home. She hung her head, staring at the sand and not paying much attention to her surroundings. At the same time, Garib strode home, similarly lost in thought. With neither watching where they were going, the pair soon collided in the street.|␣Amira recognized Garib immediately. She opened her mouth to speak but could summon no words.|␣"Are you okay, Miss?" Garib asked, his face full of genuine concern.|␣Amira took a deep breath, recalling the promise she'd made to herself. Gathering all her courage, she spoke.|␣"I'm sorry," Amira began. "It's my fault. I was lost in thought and not paying attention."|␣"It's not your fault at all," Garib smiled. "It was I that was daydreaming."|␣Amira managed a smile and tried to continue down the street when Garib raised a hand to stop her.|␣"Pardon me for being so forward," he began, "but how can someone look so sad on a night as beautiful as this one?"|␣Amira another breath before responding. "Today I said goodbye to my true love."|␣"Then you're not having a bad day at all," Garib smiled. "For today, I found out that my love never even existed!"|␣"Well, aren't we a pair," Amira said, smiling.|␣"Allow me to walk you home," Garib said, extending his arm. "The streets can be dangerous this time of night."|␣"That would be lovely," Amira said, taking his arm. "In fact, you may even ask my name on the way."|␣As the pair walked through the crowded city, the genie—cleverly disguised as a cloud above them—snapped his fingers and the people dispersed, leaving a clear path to Amira's home.|␣So ends the story that happened a long, long time ago, and while many have heard it, few believe it. Take heed, though, because every word is true.
Chapter IX
Of course I can. But what I do is not "witchcraft", my little Sheriti. I ask the gods to grant me power to perform magic… What happened?
Oh, I see! Don't you worry, Sheriti. We will definitely come up with something. But first I want to tell you a story…
Nimiru, I need your help. You practice witchcraft, don't you? For example, can you make someone forget something?
Weeell… there's just this girl who likes this one boy, but there's also another girl whom this boy likes… Basically, it's all very complicated.

I'm Nimiru, daughter of the Chief. Our city was damaged when our high priest, Menes, turned on us. We need your help to rebuild!
Hi! I'm Nimiru - the daughter of the Chief. Our city has been destroyed and townspeople are despairing. We need your help to restore the city.
Amrun, the evil spirit, has been ruling over this land for thousands of moons already. Many citizens joined his army to end their sorrows and suffering.
The prophesy says a foreigner will remove the curse from the city, restore the lost knowledge and dethrone Amrun!| |Maybe it's you?
